title: 110_s2844
content: The Beach Protection Act of 2008, also known as the Beach Protection Act, aims to identify and prevent sources of beachwater pollution. The Beach Protection Act of 2008 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include monitoring, public notification, source tracking, sanitary surveys, and prevention efforts to address beachwater pollution. Additionally, it increases the authorization of appropriations to $60,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2013. The Beach Protection Act of 2008 allows funding for monitoring and source identification programs to address beachwater pollution. States can use up to 40% of $5,000,000 and up to 50% of the remaining $45,000,000 for remediation efforts. SEC. 3. Amends the Beaches Environmental Assessment and Coastal Health Act of 2000 by changing the year from 2005 to 2013. SEC. 4. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include all environmental agencies of the State in reporting. SEC. 5. Allows the use of rapid testing methods. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include the validation of rapid testing methods by the Administrator within a specified timeframe. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to define a rapid testing method as a testing method with results available within 2 hours. SEC. 6. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require communication within 24 hours of water quality sample results to state environmental agencies. Adds all state agencies with authority over beachwater pollution prevention or treatment. Section 406(c) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include measures for developing and implementing a beachwater pollution source identification program and a publicly accessible database for coastal recreation waters not meeting water quality standards. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include measures for timely closures or advisories for coastal recreation waters not meeting water quality standards for pathogens within 24 hours of detection. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE REVIEW. Section 406(h) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include a compliance review requirement for State and local governments regarding statutory and regulatory requirements. The Administrator must provide a written assessment annually starting from the enactment date. State or local governments must comply with requirements and conditions under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Administrator will assess compliance annually and make the assessments public. Non-compliant governments must take corrective action within one year of notification. State or local governments must comply with requirements and conditions under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Non-compliance will result in a Federal share of grants not exceeding 50 percent after a one-year deadline for corrective action. The Comptroller General of the United States will review compliance by the third calendar year after enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the Administrator's activities under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act in the first and second calendar years after enactment and submit a report to Congress. SEC. 9. STUDY OF GRANT DISTRIBUTION FORMULA. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct a study to revise the formula for distributing grants under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The study will consider the length of beach season and consult with relevant agencies. A report with potential revisions is due within one year. The Administrator will submit a report to the Senate and House committees on the study results and recommendations for revising the distribution formula under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The formula will be revised based on the recommendations provided in the report.
